Module eu.lestard.easydi
Package eu.lestard.easydi

Class EasyDI

java.lang.Object
eu.lestard.easydi.EasyDI
public class EasyDI extends Object
EasyDI main class.

A typical usage looks like this: 


 EasyDI easyDI = new EasyDI();

 MyClass instance = easyDI.getInstance(MyClass.class);

  • Method Details

    • getInstance

      public <T> T getInstance(Class<T> requestedType)
      Get an instance of the given class type.
      Type Parameters:
      T - the generic type of the class.
      Parameters:
      requestedType - the class type of which an instance is retrieved.
      Returns:
      an instance of the given type.
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if there is a misconfiguration or a requested class can't be instantiated.

    • bindInterface

      public <T> void bindInterface(Class<T> interfaceType, Class<? extends T> implementationType)
      This method is used to define what implementing class should be used for a given interface.

      This way you can use interface types as dependencies in your classes and doesn't have to depend on specific implementations.

      But EasyDI needs to know what implementing class should be used when an interface type is defined as dependency.

      Hint: The second parameter has to be an actual implementing class of the interface. It may not be an abstract class!

      Alternatively to this method you can:

      • use the bindInstance(Class, Object) method to define an instance of the interface that is used
      • use the bindProvider(Class, Provider) method to define a provider for this interface.
      Type Parameters:
      T - the generic type of the interface.
      Parameters:
      interfaceType - the class type of the interface.
      implementationType - the class type of the implementing class.
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if the first parameter is not an interface or the second parameter is an interface or an abstract class.

    • bindProvider

      public <T> void bindProvider(Class<T> classType, jakarta.inject.Provider<T> provider)
      This method is used to define a Provider for a given type.

      The type can either be an interface or class type. This is a good way to integrate third-party classes that aren't suitable for injection by default (i.e. have no public constructor...).

      Another use-case is when you need to make some configuration for new instance before it is used for dependency injection.

      Providers can be combined with Singleton's. When a type is marked as singleton (has the annotation Singleton) and there is a provider defined for this type, then this provider will only be executed exactly one time when the type is requested the first time.

      Type Parameters:
      T - the generic type of the class/interface.
      Parameters:
      classType - the type of the class for which the provider is used.
      provider - the provider that will be called to get an instance of the given type.

    • bindInstance

      public <T> void bindInstance(Class<T> classType, T instance)
      This method is used to define an instance that is used every time the given class type is requested.

      This way the given instance is effectively a singleton.

      This method can also be used to define instances for interfaces or abstract classes that otherwise couldn't be instantiated without further configuration.

      Type Parameters:
      T - the generic type of the class.
      Parameters:
      classType - the class type for that the instance will be bound.
      instance - the instance that will be bound.

    • markAsSingleton

      public void markAsSingleton(Class type)
      This method can be used to mark a class as singleton.

      It is an alternative for situations when you can't use the Singleton annotation. For example when you want a class from a third-party library to be a singleton.

      It is not possible to mark interfaces as singleton.

      Parameters:
      type - the type that will be marked as singleton.
